review_title: Mixed feedback on working for Oracle Applications
pros: The transformation into a global cloud technology fosters continuous learning and groups of highly-skilled experts collaborate across lines of business and geographies to realise a compelling vision for enabling enterprise customers.
cons: The all-consuming focus on quarterly results, the adversarial corporate culture and hierarchical management style is at odds with the mission and values.  Pay rises are discouraged and the pay gap between new and long time employees is very high. On Target Earnings are hard to achieve under compensation plans designed to minimise costs rather than incentivise revenue growth.

- large amount of training available if you want it

 -
cons:
- if you don't get the right territory at the right time there is a fair bit of work you have to show

 -silver lining is new leadership doesn't know anything product related and just espouse that they are great at "execution" (which basically means updating 15 people everyday) so it's pretty easy to confuse them and drag a deal out for years whilst you golf

pros:
-Looks good on a resume
-Uncapped commissions
-You can hit "the oracle lottery" and plenty of people do
-WLB is overall good. I know most people can get their work done in 4 hours or less. Rarely working at all on Fridays. Great place if you have a side hustle. Never feel bad about taking time off here.
-In my experience the quota pressure is year-over-year and not month-over-month which offers reduced pressure on reps
cons:
Can't really share anything that hasn't been shared yet. It's funny going back over reviews from 2016 and realizing how little has changed. Here's my two cents after 5 years:

-Customers are SO unhappy. Finding a reference is impossible. It's really a corporate strategy - get them on Oracle and then they're stuck.

-Delivery of our products is awful. Partner network to implement ERP/SCM/HCM is a joke. They pass around failed implementations to one another; it's an achievement if a customer ever reaches go-live on just basic stuff. A majority of customers i've sold to never went live on our software. 

-Delivery part two: if you're the sales rep/AE, you're also customer support/customer success/implementation project manager/etc. We leave our customers to completely fend for themselves after buying. 

-Base pay raises are non-existent, even for top performers. Top top top performing AEs might get an extra 2 or 3 grand a year; even then that's really lucky and rarely seen. Presidents club recognition? Nothing - 40 billion dollar company can't expense one trip to recognize top performers. You might get a $100 starbucks gift card.

-It's entirely luck of the draw if you'll make your number or not. From SMB to upmarket. I'll be honest- that's why i've stuck around as long as I have, I've been very fortunate here. Countless others are left with 15 sales accounts that have blocked every Oracle email address or are threatening to sue us. Note - It's really astounding how many companies are threatening to sue us. 

-Hilarious micro-managing of fake pipeline, fake dials, fake everything. And this comes from the TOP of management. 

-VPs reporting to other VPs who also report to their VP and then pass along reports to their VP to meet up with their VP and VPs and VP—

-another note: BDR program /"Class Of" is really what you make of it. I've seen rockstars come out of there but it's truly fend for yourself. The current management over there is a complete joke.

-The fiscal year shake-up which everyone here has already talked about. Oracle hires more reps every year, reduces the size of your territory, has no continuity with customers. It's a total wasteland. Often this means Q1 from june-august is a complete wash with no work getting done while we wait for proper territories/comp plans/etc. Good or bad depending on how you look at that.

-Turnover in the solution engineering org is awful. All the hard working and knowledgable SEs left for competitors because they were drastically underpaid here. It's been a problem for years but never addressed. That means getting demos together can take weeks if not months. 

-Management is definitely a boys club, frighteningly non-diverse

review_title: Culture that can be improved a lot.
pros:
Excellent benefits, 
Excellent raises and stock options only if your boss gives them to you
cons:
Very rarely promotes from within the org to senior management levels these days. If you joined in 1990s you could certainly rise to senior management. But if you joined in last 10 years, you will get stuck at middle management level. If you want to really rise, quit the company go to a client or competitor and become a VP, or senior VP then Oracle will hire you back as a VP. 

Culture is of great infighting between different groups. Not of unity and collaboration and harmony but of jealousy and vindictiveness. I was pretty sure that was never the intention of senior management, but they were either never aware of this problem or if they are aware they do not know how to bring people together and make them as one people.

Great technical ideas and innovations are shot down by lower, and middle management with an excuse we don’t have time for this. So great ideas and visions never reach senior management. That is probably a problem for most large companies.

Certainly a lot of people people with egos much bigger than than their brains work here. Because they are not even ready to listen to you, then how will oracle grow and innovate at speed of light that is how fast you need to innovate to be a leader in this age.

Plagiarism is also very common. If you come up with a great idea. You might get a nasty email from your manager saying you don’t know —- a couple of bad curse words. And a couple days later you will see your slides in presentation of CTO with credits going to that same manager . Please have courtesy to simply thank people who really did the work even if you want to take credit for it.

That brings me no the next thing the use of curse words was very common. Especially by some managers and senior managers in open meetings  with 100+  participants. Not just use of curse words in general but targeted at individuals  to demean them and abuse them verbally.   Very disappointing.

review_title: 6 months WFH Experience @Oracle Financial Services Software LTD as a Fresher
pros:
- Excellent Support Framework 
- Extremely helpful seniors and colleagues 
- Flexibility of working hours during WFH (provided the requirements are delivered on time)
- Bonus and incentives twice annually
- Courses and Certifications like example OCAJP, OCI, and many more. Access to all of the premium Linkedin Learning courses 
- Shorter notice period
- Absolutely no bench period for any fresher (implies you will get assigned to a dedicated work as soon as you finish all the mandatory training.)
- Weekends off
cons:
- Hierarchical Ladder is comparatively tougher to climb (Requires at least 2+ years to jump to a Staff Consultant from Associate Consultant)
- Things might become monotonous after some time (implacable for all the service-based companies)
- It will take at least 6 to 8 months to get into the proper groove of coding work. Before that it will be more of bug fixing, code and daily DB deployments, or beginner level SQL/PL SQL assignments (this is for fresher)

pros:
I met a lot of smart, ambitious, and all around good people working at NetSuite. 

Customers were interested in meeting and they usually had nice things to say about their experience using the software. 

Oracle benefits are great. Flexible schedules were also nice. 

I was able to mentor and work collaboratively with my peers.
cons: I was tossed out after nearly two years of service. They put me on plan for 90 days starting the week before Christmas. Met the first PiP’s metrics over 60 days, so they moved it out another month until I missed. Those 90 days were the most stressful days of my life. I have a family. I was balancing taking care of a 5 year old, Covid-19, and more…None of that mattered. I was unable to hold my customers’ feet to the fire and convince them to renew their contracts early at a 20% uplift YoY so they let me go.

cons:
The usual "unlimited" vacation scam, but also going from "people take about 8 weeks a year" during the interview process to "it will seriously impact your ratings if you take more than 4 weeks, and I'll be counting the days" during work. 

Lots of talk about their corporate values, but little followthrough, especially on going back to fix things later. Frequent changes of direction made it very frustrating. They are really catering to some rather unsavoury customers, which made me feel like I needed to take a shower after work. Far too much worshipping at the altar of Enterprise Scrum.

Moving to WFH was great, except then there was a large unstated expectation that people were available for work at all hours 24/365. 

A lot of information was passed by word-of-mouth; no consistent practices across teams. And when tools were developed to solve common probvlems they were very often a forced this-fits-all. "Here is the operational model and now you need to force your product into this mold".

review_title: A good company  for long run
pros:
Free work environment and work on the base theme of "get the work done" rather than how many hours you must work.

Despite being a hierarchical organization it also acts as flat reporting when comes to managing projects.

Employees experience work pressure at pick for sure at times but all have time to relax as well.

No variable component in salary other than consulting folks and if you get a bonus that is over and above the salary in the offer letter.

Overall employee-friendly company. It provides good facilities to the employees.
cons:
Salary hike is at god mercy. It may skip increment some years.

Pay big incentive package to the new joiners but does not match the salary of an existing employee with the current market. 

Mostly you will only get to learn Oracle technologies and focus on your individual role.

Structurally it is a hierarchical organization, hence for most employees, the manager is god. You need special skills to be visible unless running a critical project which spans multiple departments.

review_title: Outdated, Antiquated, and out of Touch
pros:
Able to work remote
Fairly flexible with PTO
Not required to work a ton of hours.
cons:
Huge disconnect between sales reps and upper management
Constant annual changes/reorgs that prevent good traction within accounts
Underpaid compared to other tech competitors (Base and OTE)
Lead gen is horrific
Too many sales reps and not enough quality accounts within each territories, typically 1 rep will have majority of the good accounts (referred to internally as hitting the oracle lottery... no one ever knows how this actually comes to fruition because it is def not based on merit and 100% on luck of the draw after a reorg that comes with every new fiscal)
Referring back to the last two points, the lack of success that most reps have on top of the unrealistic expectations and robotic responses from upper management creates a toxic dog eat dog world within sales even within the same sales team and especially across different pillars (it's a wonder this company still functions and generates revenue)
Revenue is growing at a diminishing rate even with the company hitting record growth numbers in cloud. Probably due to the laughable amount of overhead (too many reps and not enough quality accounts) and VPs reporting to VPs that then report to another VP (can't keep this to just one VP... seems a bit redundant and wasteful.)

review_title: No growth opportunities, low pay, poor upper management
pros:
- medical benefits, dental benefits, vision benefits
- 401k meet
- most of the direct team knows their stuff, and will be your best friends throughout your time at Oracle
cons:
- low pay that doesn't even meet what other corporations are paying for the same position. 
- infrequent pay increases. No cost-of-living increases, either.
- no bonuses
- support is minimal, especially with a small team in a specific department
- upper management will not listen. They are not leaders; they act like "bosses". They will tell others to fix the problem; they do nothing but delegate. 
- equipment is a joke. Laptops are refurbished, and any additional equipment (e.g., additional monitors) you may need you may need to expense out-of-pocket. Laptops cannot withstand the amount of work needed to complete tasks. 
- there will be no growth within the department, and it's incredibly difficult to even try and get out of the department. Also, if you try to apply internally for other positions, you'll likely never hear from anyone about your application. It's like they want you to stay in your current position and not allow you to move anywhere.
- if you need to go into the office, you will have to pay for parking. You will not be allowed to expense the parking. Some buildings have free parking, but others are anywhere to around $25 a visit.
- overtime is frowned upon. work-life balance is completely skewed. Can easily work 14 hour days.

job_title: Lead Data Scientist in Seattle, WA
pros: A fortune 50 company in tech in your resume
cons:
TLTR: If you are coming from a better company (e.g. Google, Microsoft, Amazon, etc.), do NOT settle on 20%-30% salary increase. You'll soon regret anything less than 50% increase. 

Simply put, Oracle's culture is to exploit employees. Especially in growing organizations such as Oracle Cloud (OCI), NetSuite and Fusion Apps.

There is absolutely no perk compares to pioneer tech companies. Your salary is all you get and they explicitly expect you to work minimum 10 hours a day.
Performance reviews are all prodigy. If you've made good friendship with the decision maker, you'll get something out of it, BUT, it is not a cash bonus. It's actually RSU, so you have to work another year to realize 25% of it.

I worked at Oracle for 5+ years in different teams and organizations.

pros: Oracle is one of the best recognized enterprise brands in the world, ever. Full stop. Customers love the products, and the company has the potential to change the future of the world for the better, particularly in health care now, but also more broadly. Larry is a Silicon Valley icon and every day I feel the honor of working for the company while he still maintains a strong presence. Literally, a story for the grandchildren someday!
cons:
Executive communication is a weak point. The lack of internal sharing of information is staggering and has an impact on the performance of the company. New leaders seem to be coming in with a different mindset than those who have been with the company for decades, which is a positive. But the amount of relevant, strategic information from the top to cascade throughout the org is invisible. This is exacerbated during re-orgs, which come with major disruption to the business and could be done more efficiently and humanely.

Also, the company has set a high bar for DEI training (required 100% on participation in training and test scores) but does not require the same level of proficiency on training for its products and operations as a company. If our purpose as a company is to indoctrinate political views across the employee base, then nice job. But perhaps a little more emphasis on training people to understand the core business would be more productive.

review_title: A mixed bag of benefits and drawbacks
pros: Oracle affords you great benefits, a decent basic salary, and an interesting working environment. Oracle is a vast organization and there's always something interesting going on within it, it moves slowly but that doesn't take away from the excitement of working in a company with so many products and that's also so prominent.
cons: Oracle has strict processes that won't help you deliver, the processes are slow, cumbersome, and often work against the company. In order to stay at Oracle, you have to realize that the best thing to do is to follow the processes even if they are to the detriment of the company, trying to highlight this or push against them will be detrimental to your mental health. So simply be a cog in the machine and enjoy the benefits Oracle gives you, don't be a human, be a robot and fit in.

review_title: The long haul at Oracle and lessons learned.
job_title: PMTS Software Development Engineer in Redwood Shores, CA
pros: Tools Team can lead to interesting work sometimes. Good people. Good stepping stone job.
cons:
Hired at Market value but you fall behind and there is no reasonable path to catch up. Management (all the way up to my VP) were powerless and could do nothing to help even if they wanted to. I calculated my pay deficit over 21 years, assuming I was hired at market value, and compared what I could have made if I stayed at market value (for example, by jumping companies as soon as I fell behind) vs. what I actually made at Oracle. 21 years of starting at market that diminished to a 38% of market value resulted in a heart-breaking $1.8 million loss in pay. A hard lesson to learn.

Long periods of stagnation in title/role, even when you perform at a higher level for years. I've been a PMTS for 14 years even though I've been performing at the next level the last 5-6 years.

I averaged 12-16 hour days over 21 years.
